title.text: UvT: The UvT Term Extraction System in the Keyphrase Extraction task

abstractContent.text: The UvT system is based on a hybrid, linguistic and statistical approach, originally proposed for the recognition of multi-word terminological phrases, the C-value method (Frantzi et al., 2000).

In the UvT implementation, we use an extended noun phrase rule set and take into consideration orthographic and morphological variation, term abbreviations and acronyms, and basic document structure information.

introductionContent.text: The increasing amount of documents in electronic form makes imperative the need for document content classification and semantic labelling.
Keyphrase extraction contributes to this goal by the identification of important and discriminative concepts expressed as keyphrases.
Keyphrases as reduced document content representations may find applications in document retrieval, classification and summarisation.
The literature distinguishes between two principal processes: keyphrase extraction and keyphrase assignment.

In the case of keyphrase assignment, suitable keyphrases from an existing knowledge resource, such as a controlled vocabulary, or a thesaurus are assigned to documents based on classification of their content.
In keyphrase extraction, the phrases are mined from the document itself.

Supervised approaches to the problem of keyphrase extraction include the Naive Bayes-based KEA algorithms () (), decision tree-based and the genetic algorithm-based GenEx, and the probabilistic KL divergence-based language model.
Research in keyphrase extraction proposes the detection of keyphrases based on various statistics-based, or pattern-based features.

Statistical measures investigated focus primarily on keyphrase frequency measures, whereas pattern-features include noun phrase pattern filtering, identification of keyphrase head and respective frequencies), document section position of the keyphrase (e.g.,)) and keyphrase coherence.

In this paper, we present an unsupervised approach which combines pattern-based morphosyntactic rules with a statistical measure, the C-value measure () which originates from research in the field of automatic term recognition and was initially designed for specialised domain terminology acquisition.
